Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Floral and Faunal Community responses to Late-Quaternary Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Floral and Faunal Community Responses to Late-Quaternary Climate Change

John Williams, Stephen Jackson, Eric Grimm and Russell Graham


The PIs propose a study of the responses of species and communities to
late- Quaternary environmental variations and, in particular, the environmental drivers of species turnover, community assembly and disassembly, and the formation of no-analog communities. Their research will demonstrate the power of NEOTOMA, a new community paleoecological database that reduces informatics costs and removes barriers to interdisciplinary collaboration by storing in a single database most of the major late-Neogene paleoecological databases. The proposed research will be the first-ever synoptic analyses of late-Quaternary community dynamics in North America that directly integrate fossil pollen, plant-macrofossil, and faunal records. The PIs propose improving the resolution of the NEOTOMA database by obtaining 100 new AMS radiocarbon dates for key vertebrate fossil localities, adding recent high-quality records to NEOTOMA, revising existing chronologies in NEOTOMA in light of this new data, and mapping all data for 15 time-windows covering the last 21,000 years. These time windows are more finely subdivided than the original FAUNMAP synthesis, and will permit study of species responses to the rapid climate changes of the last deglaciation. The PIs will test such hypotheses by comparing the distributions of the floral and faunal no-analog communities to each other and to the distributions of no-analog climates. They will create plant based and animal based biome maps to see whether such maps are complementary or in contradiction. The PIs will further conduct generalized dissimilarity modeling to reveal patterns of species turnover, along environmental gradients, in both space and time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to assess changes in vegetation and mammal faunas to environmental change during the late Quaternary, the last 20,000 years.  One of the first priorities was to establish well dated chrologies for the vegetation and faunal records. To this end, the radiocarbon dates from selected vegetation sites was evaluated and rated based upon material dated, method of dating, and corroboration of dates by independent methods etc. Sites that satisfied these criteria were then selected as bench mark sites and will be used in the final analysis which is still on-going.

For the fauna, sites were selected that contained non-analog species associations. Non-analog is defined simply as the co-occurrence of taxa in a stratum that is assumed to be of one age but the taxa do not co-occur today in any geographic area. For example, collared lemmings and woodrats are frequently found together in some sites but today the lemming occurs in the tundra regions of North America and does not overlap in geographic distribution with woodrats that inhabit lower latitudes.

The only way to validate the temporal co-occurrence of the taxa is to date individual specimens of each taxon and compare the dates for their contemporaneity. As a result of this project and others, we determined that some sites do have valid non-analog associations but for other sites the non-analog species are not contemporaneous. It is apparent from this research that before a fauna can be accepted as containing non-analog taxa it is essential that the individual taxa be dated. Although, this can add to the expense of a project because of the cost of radiocarbon dates, it is essential to date the individual taxa and not assume they are contemporary otherwise.

In addition to using the radiocarbon dates for validation of nan-analog taxa, these dates can be used to map the dispersal rates of individual species. This process allows for hih-resolution mapping of changes in the geographic distribution of species through time. Again, these maps provide direct evidence for the individualistic response of species to climate change. In other words, when climate changes it does not result in the uniform shift of groups of species that can be referred to as communities. Instead, each species will respond to the environmental change based upon its own tolerance limits.

These results have profound implications for conservation biology. Instead of making a simple assumption that one type of climate change will result in the response of a whole host of species which would facilitate simple modeling, it is critical to evaluate each species on the basis of its own ecological requirements to determine potential outcomes to future changes.

This project will also provide valuable information about linkages between vegetation and mammals. For instance, in the case of tree squirrels of the genus, Sciurus, it is critical to have a wooded environment. Tree squirrels are not found in grassy environments. Instead, they are replaced by ground squirrels in open habitats. Some linkages are not as clear cut and apparent linkages between vegetation and mammals may not actually be strongly associated. If this is the case, then again the predicitions for vegetation change and mammal species change may have to follow an indiviualistic model.

We are still working on this phase of the project. The bench mark sites for vegetation have been identified.
